titleStmt.title: Despatch from ___ to Elmendorf Rothery, February 20, 1892

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

msIdentifier.repository: Ministère des Affaires étrangères, Brussels, Belgium

div1.p: Monsieur, J'ai bien recu la lettre par laquelle vous vous offrez pour représenter l'Etat à Philadelphie.

Je vous remercie beaucoup du concours que vous voulez bien vous assurer et je regrette que le Gouvernement ne soit pas en mesure d'en profiter: jusqu'à présent, en effet, l'établissement d'un consulat à Philadelphie n'a pas encore été et le choix du candidat est subordonné à la question d'opportunité.
Je tiens note, toutefois, de vos offres obligeantes en dernier et vous prie d'agréer
Rothery, Randolph and Co., Exporters and Importers, 149 So. Front Street, Philadelphia, USA Liberian Consulate.

Sir: We respectfully make application for the appointment of Mr. William Elmendorf Rothery, the senior member of our firm, to the position of representative of the Congo Free State in the United States, if you deem it advisable to make such an appointment at this time and it would not interfere with the representation of the Belgium Government already es- tablished here.

Mr. Rothery has been representing the Republic of Liberia in this city since 1888. He was born of American parents, in the city of New York, is forty years of age and has been established in business in this city for the past fifteen years.
Should your Government find it advisable to grant our request we are positive the appointment would give entire satisfaction. Very respectfully yours, Rothery, Randolph and Co.
To His Excellency The Minister of Foreign Affairs, Congo Free State, Brussels, Belgium
Mister, I received the letter by which you offer yourself to represent the State in Philadelphia.

I thank you very much for the cooperation that you want to assure and I regret that the Government is not in measure to profit from it: to date, in fact, the establishment of a consulate in Philadelphia has not yet been and the choice of the candidate is subordonate to the question of opportunity.
I hold note, however, of your last obliging offers and pray you accept
